title: 107_hr1348
content: The Act may be cited as the "Rural Law Enforcement Assistance Act of 2001". Definitions are provided in the Act. The Act, known as the "Rural Law Enforcement Assistance Act of 2001", defines key terms such as Board, Center, Executive Director, institutions of higher education, and metropolitan statistical area. The "Rural Law Enforcement Assistance Act of 2001" defines terms like rural area as outside a metropolitan statistical area and rural law enforcement agency as serving areas in rural locations. SEC. 3. EDUCATION AND TRAINING PROGRAM GRANTS. The Attorney General annually grants funds to the National Center for Rural Law Enforcement for education and training programs in rural areas, with specific requirements for use and restrictions on political support. The National Center for Rural Law Enforcement receives funds from the Attorney General for education and training programs in rural areas, including management, forensic, and computer education for employees of rural law enforcement agencies. Research is conducted on the causes and prevention of criminal activity in rural areas. Information is disseminated to assist States and units. The National Center for Rural Law Enforcement receives funds for education, training, and research on crime prevention in rural areas. It assists States and local governments by providing information and resources on criminal justice and law enforcement programs. The National Center for Rural Law Enforcement can use grant funds to enhance education and training programs for rural law enforcement agencies through various means such as providing educational opportunities, developing standards, and offering grants to carry out these initiatives. The Executive Director of the National Center for Rural Law Enforcement has the power to request employees from Federal departments to assist in formulating law enforcement policies and coordinating with higher education institutions for training programs. The Executive Director of the National Center for Rural Law Enforcement can request administrative support services from the General Services Administration and procure temporary services as needed. Additionally, the Executive Director must submit an annual report to the Attorney General detailing the education and training program developed by the Center. The National Center for Rural Law Enforcement can request administrative support services and procure temporary services as needed. The annual report must include the number and demographic representation of program attendees, use of resources from other agencies or entities, and use of contracts with other entities. $13,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. SEC. 4. REGIONAL CENTERS. The Center will establish 8 regional centers, 2 per year from 2002 to 2005, each in a specific geographic region listed in subsection (b). Region 1 includes Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New York, Rhode Island, and Vermont, while Region 2 includes Delaware and Maryland. Region 3 includes Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Mississippi, North Carolina, and South Carolina. Region 4 comprises Iowa, Minnesota, Nebraska, North Dakota, South Dakota, and Wisconsin. Region 5 consists of other states. Region 5 includes Arkansas, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Louisiana, Michigan, Missouri, and Tennessee. Region 6 comprises Colorado, Kansas, New Mexico, Oklahoma, and Texas. Region 7 consists of Arizona, California, Nevada, and Utah. Region 8 includes Alaska. Region 8 includes Alaska, Hawaii, Idaho, Montana, Oregon, Washington, and Wyoming. Funding for regional centers is determined by each center's budget request. Authorization of appropriations includes $8,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 and $16,000,000 for fiscal year 2003. Funding for regional centers in Region 8 includes $8,000,000 for fiscal year 2002, $16,000,000 for fiscal year 2003, $24,000,000 for fiscal year 2004, $32,000,000 for fiscal year 2005, and such sums as necessary for fiscal years 2006 and 2007.
